prior_works.title: Generative Flow Networks
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the core GFlowNet framework for sampling from complex unnormalized distributions via sequential construction, which this paper adapts to sample solutions of graph combinatorial optimization problems.

prior_works.title: Trajectory Balance: Improved Credit Assignment in GFlowNets
prior_works.role: Training objective for long-horizon credit assignment
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces the trajectory balance objective that greatly stabilizes and improves long-range credit assignment in GFlowNets, a key ingredient enabling effective training on long graph-construction trajectories used in this paper.

prior_works.title: Training GFlowNets with Subtrajectory Balance
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Proposes subtrajectory balance to further enhance efficiency and credit propagation on long sequences; the paper’s efficient training techniques for long-range credit assignment build directly on these ideas.

prior_works.title: Bayesian Structure Learning with GFlowNets
prior_works.role: Applying GFlowNets to constrained graph spaces
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrates how to design MDPs and rewards for sampling structured graphs (DAGs) under constraints with GFlowNets, directly informing this paper’s design of MDPs and rewards for graph combinatorial problems.

prior_works.title: Learning Combinatorial Optimization Algorithms over Graphs
prior_works.role: MDP formulation for graph CO with neural policies
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes the RL/MDP paradigm for constructing solutions to graph CO (e.g., MIS, MaxCut) node-by-node, which this work adopts and retools within the GFlowNet sampling framework.

prior_works.title: Attention, Learn to Solve Routing Problems!
prior_works.role: Neural constructive policies for CO and amortized search
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Shows the effectiveness of amortized, constructive neural policies for routing CO tasks, motivating this paper’s amortized GFlowNet policies that construct diverse high-quality solutions.

prior_works.title: Neural Combinatorial Optimization with Reinforcement Learning
prior_works.role: Pioneering neural RL for CO and solution-space exploration
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces RL-based sequence construction for CO and highlights exploration challenges; this work addresses those challenges with GFlowNets’ diversity-seeking sampling over the solution space.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core innovation—casting diverse solution sampling for graph combinatorial optimization (CO) as conditional GFlowNet policy learning over carefully designed MDPs—rests on two pillars: GFlowNet methodology and neural constructive approaches to CO. Foundational GFlowNet works (Bengio et al.) supply the sequential flow-based sampling paradigm for unnormalized targets, while Trajectory Balance (Malkin et al.) and Subtrajectory Balance (Madan et al.) provide robust long-horizon credit assignment and sample-efficient training—capabilities that are crucial when constructing large graph solutions under hard constraints. Prior applications of GFlowNets to structured graphs, notably Bayesian structure learning (Deleu et al.), demonstrate how to encode constraints and posteriors over graph spaces as rewards and MDP dynamics, directly informing this paper’s MDP design for varied CO tasks.

On the CO side, neural constructive and RL formulations (Bello et al.; Dai et al.) established the MDP viewpoint for building solutions step-by-step on graphs (e.g., MIS, MaxCut), exposing the exploration–exploitation and long-range credit challenges that GFlowNets are well positioned to address. Attention-based amortized solvers (Kool et al.) showed the benefits of amortization across instances, motivating the paper’s conditional GFlowNets that generalize across problem distributions while generating diverse, high-quality candidates. Integrating these strands, the paper leverages GFlowNets’ diversity-promoting sampling and improved credit assignment to amortize search over graph CO solution spaces, yielding efficient discovery of multiple high-reward feasible solutions.
